heading: proposal to put eu online
subheading: the european union is run by a horde of advisory committees whose legal authority is obscure. a proposal heard monday will require the committees to post their secrets online.
author: wired news report
text: several european union member countries presented a proposal monday that would force eu committees to disclose details of their meetings -- and their membership -- online. there are many committees and they tend to be secretive, making accurate information nearly possible to obtain, the guardian of london reported. the committees advise and assist the european commission, the governing body which establishes eu policies. under this proposal, committees would be required to make public documents, decisions, and agendas of those meetings.the proposal was drafted by britain and supported by germany and the scandinavian countries. it also suggests that committees be divided into three categories: advisory, management, and regulatory. this would aid in the naviagtion of information, and make it more clear what the mission of each group is.if passed, the proposal will require the committees to state their legal authority when weighing in on certain matters, a point which has been unclear in the past.according to the guardian, france, spain, and occasionally belgium have resisted any reforms of the current committee system. france and spain have formally presented reservations to the proposal, the paper said.
